content.description: Acetylcholinesterase <math alttext="or A C h E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(AChE)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is a protein that catalyzes the conversion of acetylcholine to acetate and choline. When the concentration of <math alttext="A C h E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AChE</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in an aqueous solution is held constant, the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="A C h E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AChE</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increases with increasing concentrations of substrate. At low concentrations of acetylcholine, a small increase in the substrate concentration results in a large increase in the reaction rate. At high concentrations of acetylcholine, however, a large increase in the substrate concentration results in only a small increase in the reaction rate.
content.question: Which of the following statements correctly explains the observed effect of the acetylcholine concentration on the rate of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction?

choices.label: The active site of <math alttext="A C h E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AChE</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is specific for acetylcholine, and only one substrate molecule can occupy the active site at a time.

<math alttext="A C h E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AChE</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> begins converting product into substrate as the acetylcholine concentration changes from low to high.

The <math alttext="A C h E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AChE</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein becomes denatured as the acetylcholine concentration changes from low to high.

The substrate specificity of <math alttext="A C h E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AChE</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> changes as the acetylcholine concentration changes from low to high.

content.answer: The active site of <math alttext="A C h E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AChE</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is specific for acetylcholine, and only one substrate molecule can occupy the active site at a time.
